facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 26, 1953 of the Calcutta High Court in I.T.R. No. 34 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated June 26, 1953 of Calcutta High Court in I.T.R. No. 34 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 26, 1953 of the Calcutta High Court in I.T.R. No. 34 of 1952. V. Viswanatha Sastri, Y. C. Talukdar and Sukumar Ghose, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Bhagwati J. on May 12, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with a certificate under Art. 135 of the Constitution read with s. 66A 2  of the Indian Income- tax Act raises the question as to whether the appellant ,as entitled to a deduction of Rs. 24,809

facts.text: Appellant entitled to question deduction of Rs. 24,809 for assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: raises the question as to whether the appellant ,as entitled to a deduction of Rs. 24,809 in the companyputation of its profits and gains for the assessment year 1948-49. The appellant deals in land and property and carries on land developing business and in the companyrse of the said business, it buys land, develops it so as to make it fit for building purposes and sells it at a profit in plots.

facts.text: Appellant carries on land developing business: buys land, develops it, sells in plots at profit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant deals in land and property and carries on land developing business and in the companyrse of the said business, it buys land, develops it so as to make it fit for building purposes and sells it at a profit in plots. The developments undertaken are in the main, that roads are to be laid out, a drainage system to be provided and street lights installed and they are to be maintained till the sample are taken over by the Muncipality.

facts.text: Developments include laying roads, drainage system, street lights, maintained till taken over by Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The developments undertaken are in the main, that roads are to be laid out, a drainage system to be provided and street lights installed and they are to be maintained till the sample are taken over by the Muncipality. The whole of the development is number carried out before the land is sold, number the whole of the sale price received in cash at the time of the sales.

facts.text: When plot sold, purchaser pays 25% purchase price in cash, balance with interest in ten annual installments, secured by charge on land.

anchor.surface_text: The procedure followed is that when a plot is sold, the purchaser pays about 25 of the purchase price in cash and undertakes to pay the balance with interest at a certain rate in ten annual installments which he secures by creating a charge on the land purchased. The appellant, in its turn, undertakes to carry out the developments within six months from the date of the, sale but this time is number of the essence of the companytract and what the appellant undertakes is to carry out the developments within a reasonable time.

facts.text: Appellant undertakes to carry out developments within six months from sale date, time not essence, within reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, in its turn, undertakes to carry out the developments within six months from the date of the, sale but this time is number of the essence of the companytract and what the appellant undertakes is to carry out the developments within a reasonable time. The tinderbox is incorporated in the deed of sale itself, whereas the security is given by the purchaser by means of a separate document.

facts.text: In accounting year for 1948-49, appellant sold plots, received Rs. 29,392-11-9 cash, full sale price Rs. 43,692-11-9.

anchor.surface_text: In the accounting year relating to the assessment year 1948- 49 the appellant sold a number of plots and received a portion of the sale price from the purchasers according to the scheme mentioned above. The appellant maintains its accounts in the mercantile method under which money number actually received but only treated as received on the basis that it was due and receivable is entered in the books of account on the credit side.

facts.text: Balance of Rs. 14,300 unpaid purchase price secured by charge, plus interest receivable.

anchor.surface_text: Even though the appellant did number receive the whole of the price, viz., Rs. 43,692-11-9, it entered in the credit side of its books of account the whole of that sum representing the full sale price of the lands sold during the accounting year though only a sum of Rs. 29,392-11-9 was actually received in cash from the purchaser and the balance of Its. 14,300 represented the unpaid balance retained by the purchasers the payment of which was secured by creating charge on the said lands as also the interest received or receivable in the year of account tinder the deeds of charge.

facts.text: Appellant maintains accounts on mercantile system.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant maintains its accounts in the mercantile method under which money number actually received but only treated as received on the basis that it was due and receivable is entered in the books of account on the credit side.

facts.text: Appellant debited Rs. 24,809 estimated expenditure for developments in books.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as under the terms of the deeds of sale the appellant had undertaken to carry out the developments within six months from the date of sale it estimated a sum of Rs. 24,809 as the expenditure for the developments to be carried out in respect of the plots which had been sold during the year and debited the same in its books of account on the ground that the liability for the said sum of Rs. 24,809 had actually arisen, the appellant being bound to provide the facilities it had undertaken to do, even though numberpart of that amount represented any expenditure actually made during that year.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed deduction of Rs. 24,809 for 1948-49: expenses not incurred, estimate not proved based on real expenses.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of its assessment to income-tax for the year 1948-49, the appellant claimed a deduction of the said sum of Rs. 24,809 in the companyputation of the profits and gains of its business. The Income-tax Officer disallowed that claim on the ground that the expenses had number been actually incurred in the year of account and also on the ground that the estimate had number been proved to be based on a companysideration of the real expenses which the Company would have to incur for the purpose.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed disallowance: no accrued liability, development future, current prices not allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, on appeal, companyfirmed the disallowance by the T.O. on the ground that there was as yet numberaccrued liability and on the further ground that as the development would be carried out in the future, the expenditure estimated at current prices companyld number be allowed.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held cost uncertain, expenses only when incurred, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal taken by the appellant before the Income. tax Appellate Tribunal, the Tribunal, held that it was by numbermeans certain what the actual companyt would be when the developments were carried out and that although the appellant had undertaken to carry out certain developments, it companyld bring expenses into account only when the expenses were actually incurred. The Tribunal accordingly dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: Whether Rs. 24,809 can be allowed as expense.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter made an application before the Tribunal requiring it to refer to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act certain questions of law arising out of its order. The Tribunal thereupon stated a case and referred the following question to the High Court for its decision- Whether on the facts and circumstances stated above, the sum of Rs. 24,809 can legally be allowed as an expense of the year under companysideration.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered question in negative.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of the above observations the High Court dealt with the question and after dealing exhaustively with the arguments which were urged be-fore it by the learned Counsel for the appellant answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 135 for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On an application made by the appellant, however, the High Court granted the requisite certificate under Art. 135 of the Constitution to appeal to this Court and lience, this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Rs. 24,809 deductible under mercantile system as accrued liability.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and answer the referred question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Undertaking to develop incorporated in deeds of sale: construct roads, drains, lighting, fill low lands.

anchor.surface_text: The following were the developments undertaken to be carried out by the appellant as appears from the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner- There was a companydition in the Conveyance deeds that the appellant does hereby companyenant with the purchaser that the appellant shall companyplete the companystruction of roads, drains, provide suitable pucca surface drains on both sides of the roads and shall also make arrangements for lighting up the said roads and shall maintain the said roads, drains, lights till the same are taken over by the Municipal Besides provision for roads, drains, etc., the Deed provides for filling up of low lands and there is a clause in the Conveyance Deed which shows that the appellants shall at his own companyt fi.11 the low lands and tank with earth and bring the same to road level.

facts.text: Appellant led evidence on estimated expenditure of Rs. 24,809, no exception to quantum taken.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be numbered that the appellant had led evidence before the Income-tax authorities in regard to this estimated expenditure of Rs. 24,809 and numberexception was taken to the same in regard to the quantum, though the permissibility of such a deduction was questioned by them relying upon the provisions of s.10 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Revenue accepted full receipts Rs. 43,692-11-9 including unpaid Rs. 14,300.

anchor.surface_text: Before we companyclude, we are bound to observe that having accepted- the receipts of Rs. 43,692-11-9 in their totality even though a sum of Rs. 29,392-11-9 only was actually received by the appellant in cash, thus making the appellant liable for income-tax on a sum of Rs. 14,300 which had number been received by it during the accounting year,

issues.text: whether having regard to the fact that the appellants method of accounting, viz., the Mercantile method was accepted by the Income Tax Officer and the receipts appearing in the books of account included the unpaid balance of the sale price of the plots in question, the amount of liability undertaken by the appellant to earn those receipts was to be deducted even if there had not been actual disbursement made by it during the accounting year

anchor.surface_text: The question which really arises for our determination in this appeal is whether having regard to the fact that the appellants method of accounting, viz., the Mercantile method was accepted by the Income Tax Officer and the receipts appearing in the books of account included the unpaid balance of the sale price of the plots in question,

issues.text: what was the nature of the liability which was undertaken by the appellant in regard to the development of the lands in question, whether it was an accrued liability or was one which was contingent on the happening of a certain event in the future

anchor.surface_text: Approaching the question before us in the light of the observations made above we have got to determine what was the nature of the liability which was undertaken by the appellant in regard to the development of the lands in question, whether it was an accrued liability or was one which was contingent on the happening of a certain event in the future.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 24,809 can legally be allowed as an expense of the year under consideration and the appellant is entitled to a deduction of Rs. 24,809 in the computation of its profits and gains for the assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and answer the referred question in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estimated Rs. 24,809 represents accrued unconditional liability to develop land sold, debitable under accepted mercantile system before disbursement; allowable under s.10(1) per commercial profits computation as s.10(2) non-exhaustive; quantum unchallenged.

holdings.text: The referred question is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and answer the referred question in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred; liability accrued per deeds, deductible matching receipts credited under mercantile system.

holdings.text: Under the mercantile system of accounting, expenditure is debited when legal liability incurred before actual disbursement.

anchor.surface_text: That system brings into credit what is due, immediately it becomes legally due and before it is actually received and it brings into debit expenditure the amount for which a legal liability has been incurred before it is actually disbursed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Receipts including unpaid balance credited despite no cash; symmetrically, matching liability debited; per Keshav Mills Ltd. v. CIT.

holdings.text: The undertaking to carry out developments created an accrued liability upon execution of deeds of sale, not contingent.

anchor.surface_text: noaccrued liability but only a contingent liability undertaken by the appellant, even though the undertaking was incorporated in the deeds of sale themselves.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undertaking absolute, unconditional covenant in conveyance deeds, enforceable by specific performance or cost of works; time not essence, discharge future but liability immediate; distinguished from contingent damages in Peter Merchant Ltd. v. Stedeford.

holdings.text: Nothing in the Income-tax Act prevents deduction of the debit for accrued liability in computing business profits.

anchor.surface_text: is there anything in the Income-tax Act which would prevent this debit being allowed as a deduction in the computation of the profits and gains of the appellants business? The appellant, had, it appears, claimed this deduction as and by way of expenditure wholly laid out for the purposes of its business under s. 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allowable under s.10(1) even apart from s.10(2)(xv); true profits in commercial sense require offsetting all business obligations against receipts.

holdings.text: Deductions under s.10(2) are not exhaustive of all allowable allowances in ascertaining taxable profits under s.10(1).

anchor.surface_text: it is well settled that they are not exhaustive of all allowances which could be made in ascertaining profits taxable under S. 10 1 . Venkatarama Aiyar, J., who delivered

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Badridas Daga v. CIT, Chitnavis, Gresham, Pondicherry Railway; if incidental to business per commercial practice, deductible absent prohibition.

holdings.text: The estimated amount of Rs. 24,809 is acceptable as no exception taken to quantum by authorities.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be noted that the appellant had led evidence before the Income-tax authorities in regard to this estimated expenditure of Rs. 24,809 and noexception was taken to the same in regard to the quantum, though the permissibility of such a deduction was questioned by them relying upon the provisions of s.10 2  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence led; authorities scrutinized permissibility but accepted estimate; authorities may estimate where uncertain per Gold Coast Selection Trust.

holdings.text: Revenue inconsistent in accepting full receipts without cash but rejecting matching expense.

anchor.surface_text: Before we conclude, we are bound to observe that having accepted- the receipts of Rs. 43,692-11-9 in their totality even though a sum of Rs. 29,392-11-9 only was actually received by the appellant in cash, thus making the appellant liable for income-tax on a sum of Rs. 14,300 which had not been received by it during the accounting year,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Having taxed unrealized receipts under mercantile, should allow unrealized expenses symmetrically.

precedents.citation: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1 . That system brings into credit what is due, immediately it becomes legally due and before it is actually received and it brings into debit expenditure the amount for which a legal liability has been incurred before it is actually disbursed.

precedents.case_name: Keshav Mills Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Mercantile system of accounting brings into credit what is due immediately it becomes legally due before actually received and brings into debit expenditure for which legal liability incurred before actually disbursed

precedents.citation: Peter Merchant Ltd. v. Stedeford Inspector of Taxes 1

anchor.surface_text: Peter Merchant Ltd. v. Stedeford Inspector of Taxes 1 in which a distinction was drawn between an actual i.e., legal liability, which is deductible, and a liability which is future or contingent and for which no deduction can be made.

precedents.case_name: Peter Merchant Ltd v Stedeford Inspector of Taxes
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between actual legal liability which is deductible and future or contingent liability for which no deduction can be made

precedents.citation: Gold Coast Selection Trust Ltd. v Humphrey Inspector of Taxes 1

anchor.surface_text: Gold Coast Selection Trust Ltd. v Humphrey Inspector of Taxes 1 where a particular asset which could not be immediately realised in a commercial sense was valued in money for income-tax Purposes in the year of its receipt

precedents.case_name: Gold Coast Selection Trust Ltd v Humphrey Inspector of Taxes
precedents.cited_proposition: Liabilities which have accrued can be estimated and valued for deduction even if discharged later by taking circumstances into consideration
precedents.cited_holding: It seems to me that it is not correct to say that an asset... must fix an appropriate money value as at the end of the period to which the appellants accounts are made up by taking all the circumstances into consideration.

precedents.citation: Bussel v. Town and County Bank, Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Bussel v. Town and County Bank, Ltd. The duty is to be charged upon a sum not less than the full amount of the balance of the profits or gains of the trade, manufacture, adventure, or concern

precedents.case_name: Russell v Town and County Bank Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Profits computed by deducting all expenditure necessary for earning the receipts whether actually disbursed or not
precedents.cited_holding: for the purpose of arriving at the balance of profits all that expenditure which is necessary for the purposes of earning the receipts must be deducted

precedents.citation: Gresham Life Assurance Society V. Styles 2

anchor.surface_text: Gresham Life Assurance Society V. Styles 2 - When we speak of the profits or gains of a trader we mean that which he had made by his trading. Whether there be such a thing as profit or gain

precedents.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v Styles
precedents.cited_proposition: Profits ascertained by setting receipts against expenditure or obligations to which they give rise
precedents.cited_holding: Whether there be such a thing as profit or gain can only be ascertained by setting against the receipts the expenditure or obligations to which they have given rise.

precedents.citation: Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 English authorities can only be utilised with caution in the consideration of Indian Income-tax cases

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle in Gresham Life Assurance Society v Styles is of general application

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council in the Income-tax Commissioner Chitnavis observed- Although the Act nowhere in terms authorises the deduction of bad debts of a business, such a deduction is necessarily allowable.

precedents.cited_proposition: Bad debts deductible to arrive at true profits and gains even if not specifically provided
precedents.cited_holding: What are chargeable to income-tax in respect of a business are the profits and gains of a year and in assessing the amount of the profits and gains of a year account must necessarily be taken of all losses incurred otherwise you would not arrive at the true profits and gains.

precedents.citation: Badridas Daga v. The Commissioner of Income-tax 1

anchor.surface_text: Badridas Daga v. The Commissioner of Income-tax 1 It is to be noted that while s. 10 (1) imposes a charge on the profits or gains of a trade, it does not provide how those profits are to be computed.

precedents.case_name: Badridas Daga v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Deductions under s.10(2) not exhaustive; allowable under s.10(1) if per commercial practice and incidental to business
precedents.cited_holding: when a claim is made for a deduction for which there is no specific provision in s. 10 (2), whether it is admissible or not will depend on whether, having regard to accepted commercial practice and trading principles, it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the business and to be incidental to it.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and answer the referred question in the affirmative.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; referred question answered in the affirmative allowing deduction of Rs. 24,809 as business expense under mercantile system of accounting.
directions: set aside the judgment of the High Court
answer the referred question in the affirmative
